claim: Drinking a glass of lemonade would provide Vitamin C.

supporting.text: Lemons are a natural source of Vitamin C, and lemonade made from real lemons would retain this nutrient.

attacks.text: Lemons are a natural source of Vitamin C, and lemonade made from real lemons would retain this nutrient.
Most commercial lemonades are highly processed and may lose Vitamin C during production.
Even processed lemonades often contain added Vitamin C to compensate for nutrient loss.
The amount of Vitamin C in a single glass of lemonade may be too small to provide significant nutritional benefit.
Regular consumption of lemonade, even in small amounts, can contribute meaningfully to daily Vitamin C intake.
Vitamin C degrades quickly when exposed to light and air, so stored lemonade may lose its nutritional value.
Freshly prepared lemonade consumed immediately would maximize Vitamin C retention.

supporting.text: Vitamin C is water-soluble, so it is easily extracted into the liquid when lemons are juiced for lemonade.

attacks.text: Vitamin C is water-soluble, so it is easily extracted into the liquid when lemons are juiced for lemonade.
The amount of Vitamin C extracted depends on the juicing method, and some methods may leave significant Vitamin C in the pulp.
Commercial juicers are highly efficient at extracting Vitamin C, leaving minimal amounts in the pulp.
Vitamin C degrades quickly when exposed to light and air, so stored lemonade may lose its Vitamin C content over time.
Freshly prepared lemonade consumed immediately retains most of its Vitamin C content, as degradation is time-dependent.

supporting.text: Nutritional studies confirm that citrus fruits, including lemons, contain significant amounts of Vitamin C per serving.

attacks.text: Nutritional studies confirm that citrus fruits, including lemons, contain significant amounts of Vitamin C per serving.
The amount of Vitamin C in lemonade depends on the concentration of lemon juice, which is often diluted in commercial or homemade lemonade.
Even diluted lemonade typically contains enough lemon juice to provide a meaningful amount of Vitamin C, as lemons are highly concentrated in Vitamin C.
Vitamin C degrades over time and with exposure to heat, so stored or pasteurized lemonade may lose much of its Vitamin C content.
Freshly prepared lemonade consumed shortly after making it retains most of its Vitamin C content, as degradation is a slow process.
Many commercial lemonades contain little to no actual lemon juice, relying instead on artificial flavors and vitamin fortification.
Nutrition labels and ingredient lists can confirm whether a lemonade contains real lemon juice, allowing consumers to make informed choices.

supporting.text: Commercial and homemade lemonade recipes typically include fresh lemon juice, ensuring Vitamin C content.

attacks.text: Commercial and homemade lemonade recipes typically include fresh lemon juice, ensuring Vitamin C content.
Many commercial lemonades use artificial flavorings or preservatives that may degrade or eliminate Vitamin C content.
Even when artificial flavorings are used, some manufacturers fortify their lemonade with synthetic Vitamin C to compensate.
The amount of fresh lemon juice in homemade lemonade can vary greatly, sometimes providing negligible Vitamin C per glass.
Standard lemonade recipes call for enough lemon juice to provide at least 10% of daily Vitamin C needs per serving.

supporting.text: The USDA FoodData Central database lists lemon juice as containing Vitamin C, supporting the claim.

attacks.text: The USDA FoodData Central database lists lemon juice as containing Vitamin C, supporting the claim.
The USDA database refers to pure lemon juice, not lemonade, which may be diluted or contain additives that reduce Vitamin C content.
Commercial lemonade brands often fortify their products with additional Vitamin C to compensate for dilution.
Vitamin C degrades rapidly when exposed to heat or light, so stored or processed lemonade may lose its nutritional value.
Freshly prepared homemade lemonade retains most Vitamin C if consumed immediately.
